turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 98-1167, Edward Christensen v. Harris County.
Spectators are admonished do not talk until you get out of the courtroom.
The Court remains in session.
Mr. Leibig.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

In July 1992 the county council, attorney for Harris County, Texas wrote to the Department of Labor and asked, while it is clear that the... I'm quoting from their letter to the county manager, to the Department of Labor, and they asked whether... while it was clear that the sheriff may authorize an employee to use comp time when he requests to use it, that the regulations and the statute did not make clear whether an employer could compel an employee to use compensatory time under the Fair Labor Standards Act when the employee did not want to use it, and they asked for an opinion from the Department of Labor as to whether, under the regulations and the statute, that would be allowed, and the Department of Labor answered that on September 14, 1992 that absent an agreement that was willingly accepted by the employees, an employer could not compel the use of comp time under the Fair Labor...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Agreement or understanding, is that it?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: I'm sorry... agree... yes.
Agreement...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or understanding, in terms of our understanding come in there?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: It says agreement or understanding, and also...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And do we know whether this is the case?
How many of these people were hired after this policy was already in effect?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, there's... in the record in this case it's not clear when the parties came in effect.
It came into effect sometime between 1992 and 1993.
Most of the plaintiffs were working then.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But certainly, as to any plaintiffs who were hired after 1992 or '93, if the Department said this is going to be our program, and they took the job, would that qualify as an agreement or understanding?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: It might, and I'll explain how, but it depends on whether or not that was a... clearly communicated to the employees and the employees accepted it when it was communicated.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, if they...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: In this case...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All it has to be is...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: In this case the facts are...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: clearly communicated when they accepted the job.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Excuse me.
In this case the facts are that there was a county regulation saying that comp time would be used, but it did not include an agreement with regard to compelled use.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, so far as an employee accepting... if you come to me looking for work and I say, you know, you work 40 hours a week, and you'll be paid at $10 an hour, and you go to work, you've accepted my deal, have you not?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I mean, you don't have to say... it's not a question of voluntary confession or something like that.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Right, but under the regulations and the statute, and this is in section 207(o) itself, it says the... and in the regulation, it says that compensatory time off in lieu of cash may be used, and may be a condition of employment.

There's a specific reference to the regulations that could make it a condition of employment, which I think is the question, but it says so long as the comp time agreement is pursuant... is with the individual employees and pursuant to their knowing and under... knowing and voluntary acceptance of it.

So, for example, in your accept... in your example, I could come... you could say, I want you to come to work with me for $10, which you unilaterally decided, and I could accept that, and I would be knowingly, voluntarily accepting it.

On the other hand, you could offer me the job and I could say, no, I want $15, and you could say, well then, you're not hired, but you could also say, then you are hired, and then we'd have a bilaterally determined condition of employment, and I think if you look at the regulations, while the regulations are clear that it could be a condition of employment, they're also clear that it can only be a condition of employment so long as it is accepted by the employees knowing in advance what the rules on preservation...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You're not suggesting there has to be some sort of a written acceptance.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, but at least there has to be... which there's not in this case... a clear enunciation first how the comp time will be preserved and used, and that the employer would have the authority to compel it, which didn't exist in this case.
There would be comp time, but there was no... nothing in the record, and there wasn't anything that said, we can compel use.
They adopted a... they... it says a practice in the stipulation, but it means a policy of compelling use, but that wasn't in the regulation that estopped...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What are we supposed to do about that, because I thought that everybody agrees if the employee knowingly and voluntarily agreed to the understanding...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: I think...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: at issue, then everybody agrees that then the county would win, and I think everybody... then the issue is here, though, on the assumption that they didn't knowingly and voluntarily agree, and is there now a question in the case about that so that we should send it back, or...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, the suggestion of Judge Dennis in the dissent...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: in the Fifth Circuit was exactly that.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, so what are we supposed to do about that?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: What we ask the Court to do is send the case back for reconsideration in...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Of that point.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: consistent with the Department of Labor rules.
That's what we've asked for in the complaint.

Obviously, we could have asked for, to overturn the court of appeals and uphold the trial court, but the trial court did not make findings with regard to whether or not an agreement existed and what the agreement was, therefore that's not in the record, and if you want to make it a condition of employment, first of all you have to have exactly what the agreement was and, secondly, that the employees knowingly and willingly accepted it.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Was there any allegation by the employer that there was anything other than an agreement that there would be comp time?
There wasn't any allegation that any of this was fleshed out.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No.

In fact, the employer, both in the answer to the amended complaint and the stipulation, it's clear, and in their brief, they don't claim that there was a specific provision on compelled use, and there wasn't.
I mean, in fact there wasn't, but... and neither the district court nor the court of appeals, nor the stipulation, includes that important factor...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then why would it...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: which is why Judge Dennis suggested that the trial court would have to make such a determination in order to allow any court to apply the applicable regulations.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, why would a trial court have to make such a determination if the employer is not alleging anything more than we had an understanding, they knew when they took the job that it was going to be comp time instead of overtime pay, and we didn't... we're not alleging that we spelled out the details of it.
We're not alleging that they specifically consented to this...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Compelled use.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Compelled use.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, I think the problem is in the record the way the district... the trial court did that, they didn't get to the second point where they actually said we're not alleging, the county is not... that's why I would...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In any event, you...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Even if they didn't, do you think it is a reasonable interpretation... when the employer says, you're not going to get overtime, you're going to get comp time, do you think a reasonable interpretation of that is that I can sit on my comp time, refuse to use it until I finally retire, and then cash it in...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: at time and a half?
You think that's a reasonable interpretation...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: when the employer says, what you're going to get is comp time, and my follow-up question is, do you think it's a reasonable interpretation of a statute...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: which says you can give an employee comp time instead of overtime, that it means the employee can sit on the comp time until he retires and then cash it in for overtime pay?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, I do, because the statue also says... first of all, yes, I think it's reasonable.

Second of all, the statute itself also says that there's a... expressly in the statute there's a 480-hour cap on comp time banks, and that after the employees reach that cap, they then can use the comp time, and it has... it deals with how to use it, by making requests and so forth, and therefore it... the statute doesn't give an employer a permanent right to use compensatory time.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, as I understood the statute, it was enacted in response to the complaint of the States that now that you're applying the Fair Labor Standards Act to us we're going to go bankrupt.
We cannot pay time and a half to firemen, policemen and so forth.
So Congress said, well, okay, if you want you can give them comp time instead of time and a half.
But what you're urging here, to wit, that the policemen and firemen can simply refuse to use the comp time.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Right.
That's because...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And then get it in cash.
It just makes... it just makes nothing of the concession that Congress made to the States.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Justice Scalia, I would argue that the Congress didn't quite make as broad a concession as you indicated, because...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, I...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: first of all the statute itself says that an employer may use comp time only pursuant to an agreement with the employees, and only pursuant to a number of other conditions.
The statute also says, delegates to the Department of Labor to make regulations about what that means, and the Department of Labor has made regulations that make precisely clear what those are.

In addition, while the legislative history indicates that Congress was trying to respond to Garcia and allow employers to operate more efficiently, the legislative history is also clear that the comp time provisions were meant to accommodate preexisting arrangements between employers and employees, and that they weren't the major part of the cost saving.

They gave greater flexibility to the employer, but the statute and the legislative history repeatedly is also clear they gave a right to the employees to use it to control the comp time in the legislation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Leibig...
Within reason.
Mr. Leibig, let me get the procedural history of this case straight.
The district court granted summary judgment for your client.

It went to the Fifth Circuit, the Fifth Circuit granted summary judgment for the county and Judge Dennis said, really neither side should get summary judgment, and your position here is that Judge Dennis was correct?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Our position, and what we asked for in both of our briefs, is that the case should be remanded for further hearing in terms of the Department of Labor regulations, which required the investigation of the extent and meaning of the agreement and how the agreement fit into the rules.
That's basically correct, Your Honor, and the... I would...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Could I ask you what Department regulation covers this exactly, and where we might find it in the material with this case?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Basically, that the... covers compels use exactly?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
The regulation that deals with it is 553.23, and the...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Where do I find that...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: in these materials?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: In the appendix, the original appendix to the petition, which contained most of the appendix, at page 46...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Just a minute.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I would look at the petition for...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: It's the white... the white large...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: This?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And where would I...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: It's 46a.

There's a couple of things, but the first is 46a, and that is... 553.23(a)(1) describes how you get an agreement, and then (2) says the... it deals with the agreements, and this is a discussion of the kind of things that would be in an agreement, and...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Where does... where do I find language here, on page 46a, that tells me the employee does not have to use it?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, you don't.
I mean, I was... as I say, I have to go to a couple of places.
What it says there is that the agreements for comp time may include provisions governing preservation, use, and cashing out of comp time.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: And then in addition to that it says in... back on page 45, it says agreements of understanding may provide comp time off.
In addition to the agreement an understanding may be a combination... it goes through the various things that would be in a comp time agreement.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I think everyone agrees that there can be an agreement covering it.
Where do I find in the regulation a directive about what happens absent an agreement?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: As the letter that I cited from the county, in the regulations themselves there's no express treatment of the compelled use question.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So to what do we defer, then, in terms of the Labor Department?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: The Department of Labor's interpretation of their own regulations, which is expressed... well, first of all, there's three of them.

First of all, it's expressed specifically in the letter... the specific letter, which in this case was actually a letter to Harris County saying compelled use, they interpret this regulation to prevent compelled use, and that relies on their interpretation of this regulation, plus I think it's important...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Who is that letter from?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Who did that letter come from?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: It came from Harris County's... specifically asking about the facts of this case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: To the Labor Department?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Went to the Labor Department.
It was by the Administrator of the Wage & Hour Division.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The administrator...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Right, and that was September, I think 14, 1992.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And where is that?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Of the letters... the letter itself is not reprinted in the record, but it's cited in all the briefs in this...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So that's all we have, really.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No.
Well, I wanted to... no.
And then in support of that, the question is, how did the Department of Labor get from the regulations to the thing, and there's two things in support of it.

First of all, the legislative history itself, of the... the congressional legislative, both the House and the Senate report, refer to the right of employees to use comp time 10 times and they refer to, 14 times, that it's a benefit of the employees, and that the employees can cash out comp time.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, these are all statutory provisions.
Let me ask you this.
There's no collective bargaining agreement here...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: covering this...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: There's an earlier case before the State.
In Texas and Harris County, collective bargaining is illegal.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: There is no collective bargaining agreement that we worry about here?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, that's correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Can the employer say, well, maybe it wasn't clear in the past, but I want to make it clear from this date forward, if you want to continue to work here, you're going to have to use your comp time, so if you want to stay a county employee, that's the rule?
Can they do that?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Under the statute and regulations they can do that, and then the employees have the option of then either accepting it and continuing to work...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Or leaving.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Or... and by the way, under the regulations they not only could... the regulations both provide a condition of employment with those conditions.

They also provide, in 553.23(c)(1) at the bottom that you could just give notice, which... there may be... I'm not sure there's a debate, but there may be a condition between making a condition of employment and giving notice, but it also says if they give notice that we will have compelled rules, and if the employee then works a day after that, it can be presumed that he accepted it, but then if...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, has the county give notice here...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: do you think?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, because it also says that if the employee...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: These employees don't know that the county thinks they have to use...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, the regulation also says if the employees fail to express an unwillingness to accept it, it will be presumed, but in this case the employees did express an unwillingness to accept it, and therefore the opposite presumption I think would occur, and again you have to read the last two sentences of the section I cited, so that in this case, first of all...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You mean, if the employee says nothing, then the county has to either fire them or assume that the deal's off?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No.

I think the rule is if an adequate notice is given and the employee says nothing and works, the presumption is that he accepted it, but if he expresses an unwillingness to accept it, then the presumption is that he did not accept it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But then...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Then if the employer lets him continue to work, he doesn't... can't compel him to use comp time, but he would have the option to terminate.
I mean, if they think it's that serious a thing to do, why, that would happen.
In this specific case all those cases, facts haven't been developed, but I think that's the way it would go.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I presume they would also have the option to say, we're not going to fire you, but if you won't use the comp time, we're simply going to reduce your weekly hours to 35 a week.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, I think they could, 1) say we're not going to let you work any more overtime.
Whether they could reduce their hours to a low, or below the statute...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They're saying, look, we're doing it because we've got this great overhanging liability out there, and the only way we're going to be able to fund it is to save money in some other way.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, first of all...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And the wage and hour law doesn't tell us how many hours we have to let you work.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: The regulations say that the employee's decision to accept comp time has to be made free of coercion or pressure, and that's clear in the regulations and the legislative history.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But firing is not coercion?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, because...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You say you can fire him, but I can't reduce your hours to 35?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Well, the regulations say you can make it a condition of employment, so if you make it a condition of employment, the person is free whether to accept the job or not, but if they do accept the job, then it is the system covered by the regulations, and part of this is to make sense out of all the regulations and the legislative history.
If the legislative history, which is trying to...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If possible.
If it says that, I don't call that making sense out of it.
You can fire him, but you can't reduce his hours...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, no.
I think you can reduce his hours unless you've expressed to him the intent of your reducing his hours is in order to pressure him into accepting comp time.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, I'm not...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: But other than that...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I'm not pressuring him.
He can keep his saved up time in the bank.
I'm not telling him he's got to draw that down.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And he'll get... if he keeps it till the end he'll get paid time and a half.
I'm simply saying, I've got to provide for my liability, and therefore I've got to employ people less hours in order to put the money aside for a rainy day.
Is that coercion?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No, I don't think it is...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: in that context.
If the employee could demonstrate actual coercion they may have an argument in the case, but absent that...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But the example that I just gave you would not, as a matter of law, be coercion, you concede?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: I don't think so.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Also I think that, along the same lines because I want to make it clear, the odd thing about this case is the burden between the employer imposing this without an agreement with the employees, and what he would have to do to get an agreement, is not a long road.
The facts in this case are, they imposed compelled use without either the notice, the condition of employment, or...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In fact, the road isn't any longer than my hypothetical, is it?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: We know it's going to happen.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Right.
In addition to that, though, one thing in your hypothetical, that you assumed that the county would save money by paying people in comp time rather than cash, and I don't think Congress assumed that.
There's a slight additional flexibility.
In fact...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I was assuming some fat there.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I must be...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Comp time in fact would cost more than...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You have to... I may have to...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: so they may want to avoid it by paying it out later, but they...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Enlighten me about what you mean by saying paying in comp time instead of cash.
If they take comp time, don't they get paid in cash for the time they don't work?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

That's what I was trying to explain, but they do, but hypothetically there's a slight way they can... it can cost the employer more, because if the employee is making $10 an hour in 1992, works for comp time and then banks it as Justice Scalia suggested, and then cashes it in 5 years later, probably he'll be making $12, so that could cost... over the long haul that could cost the employer a little bit more money.
Now, the...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, but that's...

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: In fact, you have a defense against that, because the employer is free at any time to cash out the contract, so they could avoid that, not only by cashing out the comp time, but I suggested in my brief three or four other ways that an employer can protect themselves from that happening, but in theory that's the additional cost of comp time if it's stored, and so...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if he... of course, as the employer used his comp time a year later and the wage rate's gone up, the time he uses the comp time he will stay home and get paid at the rate... then current rate, will he not?

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: If he waits till he retires, there's another rule.
He either gets the regular rate or the higher...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, in the meantime the employer's had the use of the money, too.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Yes, and inflation's... but I'm just saying, other than that, and Congress is clear about this both in the regulations and the legislative history, Congress' view was that you're not supposed to use comp time... they meant comp time to be an equivalent of being paid in cash, because eventually you have to pay the money, and in fact in the real world it works out there would be areas I've described, and as we've described in our brief, there are methods by which the employer can save it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Leibig.

turn.speaker: michael_t_leibig
turn.label: Mr. Michael T. Leibig
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Roberts, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
An employer may not require an employee to use his comp time against his wishes unless the employee has agreed to that arrangement in advance.
That conclusion follows from two features of the act.
First, the act gives the employee the absolute right to overtime pay in cash.
An employer cannot substitute comp time for overtime pay in cash unless he first secures the employees' agreement.
Second, the act makes clear that comp time is a substitute for cash pay.
An employee has the absolute right to use that cash pay as he pleases.
The employer can't tell the employee when or how it may be spent.

Just as the control over cash is a central aspect of its value, control over the use of comp time is central to its value, and therefore the Secretary has reasonably construed the act to permit the employee to use the comp time he has earned as he wishes, except to the extent he's otherwise agreed...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, where do we find some departmental regulation that spells out what happens...

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Well, the Secretary has construed its... her regulations to provide that in reliance on three provisions in the regulations.

First, section 553.23(a)(1), which is on page 45a of the joint appendix, which provides, just as I explained that the statute did, that comp time is a substitute for overtime payment in cash, and that there must be an agreement with the employee.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, that doesn't get you there.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That just says there has to be an agreement before you can use comp time.
It doesn't say what the consequence of using comp time is.
I mean, it just says there has to be an agreement before you can use comp time.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and the Secretary is also relying on the provision in (a)(2) that says that the agreement may include provisions governing the use of comp time.
That's on page 46a...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: the first sentence, and also relying on (c)(1), which is on page 47.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, let's do (a)(2) first.
An agreement may contain other things.
It doesn't say it must contain other things.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, the regulation could have said that.
Any other things... you know, any other conditions on comp time must be included in an agreement.
It doesn't say that.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: The regulation doesn't require that it address that, but the Secretary has construed the regulation as a whole to mean that if it doesn't address that, then the employee retains the right to use comp time...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, why on earth doesn't the Secretary say that in a regulation, rather than having to construe something that's ambiguous.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Well, the Secretary didn't address it in the regulation, but did address it in the opinion letter, which provides clarification of the regulation...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, it still...

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: and the Secretary's interpretations.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I just want to... I may be misremembering this, but I can't... let's just ask you that even if it's not a formal interpretation of the regulation, which I could see how it would be, what it means to say you can put extra conditions there, in terms of the... a background rule where nobody says anything.

I could understand that, but even if not, isn't there a famous administrative law case, Skidmore, which talks about this Court paying deference to a wage and hour administrator on the ground that even if he lacks... he possesses the power to persuade even though he lacks the power to control?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
We contend that the interpretation of the regulation is entitled to stronger deference that Skidmore.
Skidmore was decided...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I never knew there was a difference of deference.
I never was able to measure it.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Well, the courts of appeals, and I think this Court as well, recognized a difference between Chevron-type deference or the kind of deference in our, and what might be called Skidmore-type deference, which is that the... reasoned judgment is entitled to respect for its power to persuade and...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I mean, all we're talking about is, what is the background rule if, in fact, nobody puts a condition in the agreement?
Now, they're free to put it in or not, but what's the background rule, which is a pretty sort of interstitial minor point, isn't it?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
It imposes very little burden on the employer.
The employer is well-situated to obtain the employee's agreement to that condition, and...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask, Mr. Roberts, what's the opposite rule?
If the employer can't decide when it's used, does the employee have the right to say, well, I've decided to take it whenever I choose?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: The employee has the right to use comp time within a reasonable period when the employee requests it, unless it would unduly disrupt the employer's operation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, excuse me.
I thought he doesn't have to use it within a reasonable time.
I thought the position here is that he can sit on it and choose not to use it as he wishes, and cash it in at the end of his career?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: The employee can accrue the comp time so that the employee can use it on request, as provided by 207(o)(5).
The employee also could accrue it up to the maximum provided by the statute.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He has no obligation to be reasonable in his use of it at all, isn't that right?
I thought that's what we're arguing about here.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: He has an obligation to not... he's unable to use it on request if it would unduly disrupt the employer's operation, but...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Doesn't that cut against... I'm just trying to think it through.
Doesn't that in a way cut against you, in the sense that there is a restraint on the ability of the employee to use it whenever he wants to.
He can't just say on Friday I'm going to take off next Monday and Tuesday.
He must consider the employer's wishes, but there's no restraint on the employer's imposing, under the regulation, his desires on how it should be used, no express restraint.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Because Congress did not expressly address the situation when the... if the employer could require the employee to use comp time.

I submit that that's because Congress didn't conceive that the employer would assert that authority, because Congress understood that the comp time belongs to the employee, and that the employee would ask when to use it and not be told when to use it, and that follows, as I said, from the features of the act that I described earlier, so Congress didn't have a need...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the Congress did impose a ceiling on how much comp time that could be accumulated.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes, but once that ceiling is reached, Congress specified that the employee would have to be paid in cash, which returns the employee to getting his basic rate under the act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But what I don't understand, Mr. Roberts, is what good it does for Congress to say, you don't have to pay these people cash.
You can let them have comp time instead.
I don't see what good that does if Congress also says, oh, and by the way, the employees don't have to use this comp time.
They can just sit on it and bank it, and cash it in at the end of their careers.
What has Congress accomplished?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Congress doesn't say you can pay these employees comp time.

It says, the employees have the right to overtime pay in cash, and the employees may agree with you when it's mutually beneficial to get comp time, and those mutually beneficial arrangements may save the employer money, but Congress was very clear, the statute is absolutely clear, the employee has the right to overtime pay in cash.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If they decide to bank it and never spend it, and the employer would like them to, and eventually get cash for it, when do they get the cash, when they retire?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: If they bank it, they get... they can accumulate under the 240 or 480 hours, and on termination of employment they have to...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: On termination of employment, so it's quite possible that... it would be an unusual case where they'd want to bank it.
I mean, if you refuse it you get paid time and a half next month, and if you decide to take the comp time and save it, you're going to be paid when you retire.
Do you get paid more when you retire?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: You get paid... you might get paid more, but I don't think it would be worth more 20 years down the road.
You would get paid at the rate then.
It's unlikely...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, at the rate for your rank then, to.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: At the rate for your rank then, or the last 3 years.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If you're a captain then you'd get a captain's 240 hours, right?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor but...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They must not make decisions based on these prospective calculation of what it's worth years down the road, or maybe they do, do they?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: I don't know whether they do.
There's no indication in this case that these employees wanted to do that.

Another feature of their complaint, which wasn't pursued on appeal, was that they were not being allowed to use comp time when they requested to do so, so it suggests that they did request to use comp time.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Roberts, does it come down to whether the default rule is, you get overtime, or the default is, as Judge Hickinbotham said, the employer sets the work rules?

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes.
You could look at it that way.

The reason that the default isn't that the employer sets the work rules is that Congress has displaced that principle that the employer can set the rules in the act by making... by giving the employee the right to overtime and by providing that the employer can only have a comp time arrangement pursuant to the employee's consent.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The question is, how detailed the consent must be.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Just the comp time, or the working out of it.

turn.speaker: matthew_d_roberts
turn.label: Mr. Matthew D. Roberts
turn.text: Yes.
That's the issue, and it is simply a default rule.

The parties... everyone agrees the parties can contract out of that principle, so it's not imposing an onerous burden on the employer, and what it is doing is furthering the underlying scheme in the act.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Roberts.
Mr. Fleming, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

One reason, or the main reason on why there aren't any regulations that address this issue, and there really aren't, is because of the... what's really taking place in this, what's been termed a forced use of compensatory time.
The Fair Labor Standards Act basically provides for a minimum wage rate and maximum number of hours.
There's no provision in there that guarantees a 40-hour week, work week.

An employer is always free to cut the work week short, to have an employee work 30 hours, 20 hours, 10 hours, 1 hour, and in the Fair Labor Standards Act there's a very specific provision that allows employers to cash out accrued compensatory time at any time.
It's in the statute and more specifically in the regulations.

Now, if they could do each of those two separately, there's nothing that prevents a public employer from doing so simultaneously to achieve the objectives which were set out in the amendments following the Garcia decision, that is, to protect the county's resources and budgets and really, in this situation, to protect against employees that do bank their comp time and hold it to the maximum.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You mean, the employee normally has a 40-hour week, say, you just come in 35 hours this week, I'll pay you for 40, right, and the other 5 will be paying down your comp time, right?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, Justice Scalia, and in fact...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So what's the big deal, then?
Why do we have this case in front of us?
Why don't they just do that?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That's what we do.

What happens is that they'll... after the supervisor tries to reach an agreeable time for the employee to start taking time off and getting paid in cash from their compensatory time that's been accumulated, if the employee doesn't do it, then he meets with him and orders him to do it, and still tries to get a reasonable period of time when they can do it, and if not, then issues an order for the employee to do it.

And what will happen is, for instance, if it's a week the employee is going to take off, the employee doesn't come in to work that week but he still gets his paycheck, 40 hours of pay, and mind you, that pay has been accumulated at time and a half, so they're still getting the benefit of the time-and-a-half provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
That's what the practice is, and that's what happens.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, why don't you put it in an agreement?

I mean, you know... that's what I don't understand, is why is this case such a big deal, since everybody agrees you should be able to do that, but you have to get your employees' agreement to it, just as you'd have to to get his agreement to comp time in the first place, and so you have to get that agreement anyway.
What's the big deal?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: I think...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And if there are good arguments on both sides, which there are, you could have a background rule either way.
The reg, I agree with you, doesn't say much about it.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And so why not just go with the agency?
I mean, that's a... why... you know, trivial matter, interstitial, background agreement, they have the experience, et cetera, et cetera.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So that's sort of where I... what I'm thinking about it.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is your response?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That's a good question, and in addition to the default rule, which Judge Hickinbotham of the Fifth Circuit said, where he sort of filled in the gaps of what he perceived the agreement would be, in addition to the fact that under the statute we don't have to have an agreement, is our position, really how the case evolved, though, is up until we got to this Court the petitioner was saying that it's completely prohibited by the act, agreement or no agreement, and it was our position that it's... we're allowed to do it by the act, and that's still our position.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, and now in this Court everybody agreed that there can be an understanding.
We're talking about what notice the employees have to be given, so there's no question that from now on Harris County can say, this is the deal, employees.
The only question is when they didn't say that, when all they said was comp time, what should be the consequences?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Well, we agreed that we could do it by agreement, but it's our position we don't have to do it by agreement, and whether we want to go back and issue a new...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, what's the it?
I mean, certainly you can't substitute comp time for overtime pay except by agreement or understanding.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Right?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That's...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So you must have an agreement to comp time.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Which we have.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And the question is, what are the terms and conditions of that comp time?
One we know from the statute, that the employee can request it, and the employer has to accommodate unless the time that is being sought would unduly disrupt...

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: operations.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So we have that one condition on it directly out of the statute.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But why, if Congress is trying to say, employees, it's your option, or at least you have to be given notice, why shouldn't that notice be, here it is, and at a certain point you're going to have to take it?
Why shouldn't that be spelled out, instead of the employee thinking, well, this is fine.
If I need it, I'll use it, and if I don't need it, I'll bank it, and the statute says after X number of hours I get paid in cash.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I agree that it can be in an agreement, certainly.
But just as the Fifth Circuit said, that there are workplace rules which the employee governs, in this case, this is something that is outside of the act.

They could be... setting the number of hours below 40 is not covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act, and the employer is not required to enter negotiations with the employees on when they're going to set those hours or cut them back.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is that what you did here?
I am in some perplexity.

I thought your opponent had acknowledged that it would be okay for the employer just to say, next week only come in 35 hours, and for the employer to take the money that it saves, the 5 hours, add a little bit more to it for the time and a half, and voluntarily, as it's entitled to do, buy out 5 hours worth of the comp time.
Now, is it common ground that that is okay?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: I don't know if... I don't think that's what the petitioners are maintaining.
That's our position.
We're telling them, don't come in next week, or, you know, in a couple of weeks...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, you're doing something a little different.
You're saying, don't come in next week, take your comp time instead.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Right?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That's what... as we have maintained, we're doing two things, and they...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's a little different from saying... you're directing them to take their comp time.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which means, you know, they won't get any... well, they'll get their regular pay, and they'll have time and a half off, I guess, right?
Is that how it comes?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.
I mean, they've accrued the comp time for time and a half, and...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that... it seems to me that's a bit different from simply saying, look at... God, you've got 240 hours here.
I can't afford that.
Don't come in for 5 hours next week.
Say nothing else about the comp time, and then the employer just buys off 5 hours worth of comp time.
That's a little different, and I'm not sure that the other side says that that's bad.
That's not what you've done here, though.
You've instructed them to take their comp time.
Isn't that the facts of the case?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, but by doing it, it's in two phases.
I agree that it's a forced use, but as far as finding a statutory authority for doing it, it's the way I explained.
There's nothing that can stop us from shortening the work week, and we can cash out the comp time at any time without any restrictions.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why don't you do it the other way, and save us all this trouble?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But I think that was the answer to my hypothetical.

I said, what if they... if they do nothing but say, we've got to make up some money somehow to pay for this overhanging liability, so we're only going to employ you 35 hours a week, and I understood your friend on the other side to say that would not be coercive, and that would be okay.
In practical terms, that would get you exactly where you want to go.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: You mean... if I understand your question...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Because... excepting in one case.
If the employee says, all right, by Godfrey, I'll work 35 hours a week, but nothing is going to induce me to touch my accrued comp time.
That nest egg is going to stay there until the day I retire.
The employee could do that.
In the real world, I presume that would not happen.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He can't do that, can he?
Doesn't the employer have a right to buy out the comp time?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: The employer has a right to buy out the comp time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's the issue.
You can make him work 30 hours a week, but the question is, can he refuse to be paid for 40?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: No, because we can cash it out.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's your position.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That's...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: His position is, he can say I don't want to take the 10 hours in cash, I want to keep it in the bank.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: I don't think that they're saying that they can refuse to take the payment, because the statute and the regulations are very clear about that, cash them out at any time, and so if we can do either of those separately, we can do them simultaneously.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And that's what protects the employer against excessive accumulations.
The employer can always say, well, the main rule is time-and-a-half pay.
Here's your pay.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.
We can cash them out.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That...

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: The employer can cash out at any time.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But then, if you look at it as the comp time being an exception to the overtime pay, then it would be logical to say the employer can go back to what is the main rule, what is the rule in workplaces that are not public.
There's no comp time option in the private sector, is there?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So the underlying premise of the Fair Labor Standards Act is, you pay time and a half.
Then there's an exception that operates only in the public sector, but Congress has provided that the employer can always do what employers all over the country must do.
That is, pay time and a half.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Pay time and a half, or we can cash them out.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, that's what I mean by cashing them out, by... instead of letting them accumulate the time, giving them the money.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, as they... as they're accumulating it, if we... when they reach the 240 hours, if they do, if we don't cash them out they're going to get time and a half.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I confess to total stupidity here, because if you've got your 30-hour-a-week example, you say you have an absolute right, and they don't contest the fact you can pay them for the extra 10 hours if you want to.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what exactly does...
Then why aren't you doing that?
I don't understand why that isn't... what you're fighting about, if everybody agrees you can do that.
Isn't that just making them take 10 hours of comp time each week?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: If we did it each week, we could.
We don't do it each week, though.
I mean, they wait till it gets up to near the maximum of 240 hours in our case, and then they try and get it to come down a little bit, so they're not cutting back their time every week.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Give me a specific example of what cashing out means.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Cashing out is if an employee has some accrued compensatory hours, whether it's 1 hour or 240 hours, that the employer can pay for those hours in... at the... whatever rate the employee has at that time, or... and they can also do it when the employee leaves or is terminated, and they pay it out dollar for dollar based on the number of hours.
Now, the hours have been accumulated at time and a half.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.
There is no such thing as comp time for regular... for not overtime, is there?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: No, there's not.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I want to go back to your answer to Justice Stevens' question.
If I understand it correctly, what this case boils down to is this.

If you reduce hours on a regular basis, and you also choose to cash out a portion of the accumulated time every week, no problem, no argument, but if you do it on an irregular basis, if you make a judgment that the fire department, sheriff's department says, gee whiz, next week we haven't got much process to serve, so I think we'll make so-and-so take Wednesday afternoon off, not a regularly scheduled thing every week, an irregular judgment from time to time, that's what we're fighting about?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: I don't want to state the petitioner's position, but...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's what you think we're fighting about?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.
Well...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not even as substantial as that.
You could, on an irregular basis, say we have so many... so few processes to serve next week, you know, Jones, take next Wednesday off.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right?
And then make the decision to pay Jones... pay Jones' comp time down.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: If Jones didn't have any accrued compensatory hours we could do that.
He gets nothing.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you don't... it really doesn't... it doesn't make any difference, and that leaves me in something of a quandary, whether the fact that it doesn't make any difference means that we should find for your opponent, because you can do what you want to do anyway very easily, or the fact that it doesn't make any difference should make me wonder why it should be prohibited to do it the more honest way by the Fair Labor Standards Act, why...

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't know which resolution that leaves you with.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: See, Justice Scalia, in looking at the Fair Labor Standards Act, there's nothing in there that prohibits us from doing this.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But it's symmetry.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Well, it's symmetry...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You see, basically the statute says, we prefer money.
You work overtime, we'll give you money.
Now, you work overtime, you get the money.
Now, if you agree to take the comp time, that's fine, and that kind of idea, that it's money or you get their agreement... it says its money and they get their agreement, they get the comp time.
It says it's money, or you get the agreement if you want to force them to take the comp time rather than wait till the end and get the cash, all right.
I mean, it's symmetry.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: It's symmetry, but if you go back to what Justice Scalia said at the very beginning of the argument, was that the purpose of these amendments in the first place was to help out the governmental entities so they can manage their budgets and wouldn't have to pay this overtime in cash, and it was expected that the employees would use the compensatory time, and not expected that they would bank it...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I don't see why most of them don't, to tell you the truth.
I mean, why are they going to wait around for 20 years and cashing it out, instead of... don't most of them?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Well, if they don't do it...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: okay, and we get to the position where they're reaching the maximum level and the Government's going to have to start paying time and a half in cash, then a fair reading of the...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Do we know any facts here, by the way, what actually happens?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: There's nothing in the stipulation, which is basically the record, as to exactly how many this occurred would amount to the...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It is not an unknown phenomenon in the Federal service for some people to save up sick time, which they're entitled to be compensated for at the end of their service, and it was not an unheard-of practice for people to save up vacation time, which is why some employers require you to take your vacation, because people would work the whole year and then, you know, save up all their vacation time, retire a year earlier.
I don't think it's at all fanciful to think that people would bank this stuff.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What about the other... sorry.
Did you want to answer that?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Oh, I agree that... I mean, it's easy to see that people will do it, but under the act and the '85 amendments it was expected that people were going to use it, and that was their concern, is that the employees have the time, and the Fair Labor Standards Act makes sure that people aren't overworked, without getting paid time and a half for it.
It's not to make sure they get to work 40 hours.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could you explain something else to me?
I think we understand now the 30-hour... you can make them work 30 hours a week, and pay them the extra 10 even if they don't want that.
How is it that you are in fact compelling them to use their comp time if it's not by that example?
What do you do to them when they get 220 hours, and they're getting close to 240?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How do you... what is the arrangement which makes the expend their comp time?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: They're told to do it.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They're told...

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That is how we're doing it.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: That is how we were doing it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You make them work 30 hours a week instead of 40?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: And 30's just an example, but it's, they're going to take the time off...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Short week.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: And then we're going to cash you out under the act, some of your hours, to make sure you get a full paycheck.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So they get the same paycheck that they would if they had worked the regular hours?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: They get the same paycheck, but they haven't had... they've got... the hours that are cashed out they accumulated at time and a half anyway, so that it's for a less amount of work, so they do get the same pay.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But you require... I mean, you require them to give you a slip of paper saying, I choose to take my comp time, or something like that?
No?
You just say, you are taking your comp time?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: They are asked to start reducing it voluntarily.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Just under the stipulation.
If they... and within a reasonable time.
If they don't do it...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If they don't do it, then what?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Then the supervisor can order them to do it, and try and... and still work with them to try to reach mutually agreeable times, but the effect is an order to do it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, to the extent you're talking now beyond the stipulation the record simply isn't developed, I suppose.
Do you feel you can speak for every division of the county government on this, that this is exactly how they do it?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: No, just as to the Sheriff's Department, which is the defendant in the case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The Sheriff's Department is the only defendant in the case?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: The county is a defendant as a result of the Sheriff's Department.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: All that's being challenged are the practices in the Sheriff's Department?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If it's proper for you to do what we have been assuming in these hypotheticals you could do, why does the statute place a cap on the amount of comp time that can be accumulated?
There's absolutely no need to do that.
You and other employees can... employers can protect yourselves.
The cap implies to me that you don't have the autonomy that we have been assuming here.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: The cap, I believe, is for those employers that just don't... can't or won't let the employees take the time off, and I think the concerns when these enactments of '85 went into effect was that the employees are able to use the time, are able to take the time off.
On the other side...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So they're protective devices so that we do not build... the employee does not build up so much comp time that the employer in effect is not, at the end of the road, going to be able to pay it.
It's for the protection of the employee, you're saying.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: It's a balancing.

An employee's protection is this, is that in the statute, as was mentioned, the employee is allowed to use it within a reasonable time if there isn't an undue disruption, and so the focus there is on the employee's ability to use the time.
On the other side, the employer's controls over this, since it is a balance, is the employer's ability to cash them out.

And I might add that on the ability of the employers to cash them out, it's an important distinction, because it is... that division gives the employers control, and the petitioners have maintained well, this comp time accumulation is under the sole control of the employees, and there certainly would be circumstances where the employers would choose to cash out the comp time, and it would be contrary to what the employees wished to do, such as if they wanted to stop them from using it at a certain time of the year, or if there had been an increase, county-wide budget increase in pay, the employer, the Department could cash them out before that goes into effect.

That hasn't been done in this case, but in... that certainly reflects that the act provides the employer with a certain degree of control over these comp time hours, and it's not within the sole discretion of...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, why doesn't that just underscore that the default rule should be, you pay them, not, you set the work rules any way you like?
I mean, the statute says, there's an exception, but the main rule is time and a half.
If the main rule is time and a half, then it's perfectly logical for the statute to say, you can... employer, you can always pay time and a half.
You can do the other if the employees agree to it, but you can always go down to the bedrock rule under the Fair Labor Standards Act, which is time and a half.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, they could, once they go over the 240.
Yes, Justice Ginsburg, that's correct, you could do that.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
