turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you could cash out the credits at any time, right?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, that's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And so it does suggest to me that this is a statute where the main rule is time and a half, but you have an exception.

Usually we construe exceptions narrowly, not broadly, and if Congress' idea is, let the workers know what you're doing, then it's just a question of notice, and you didn't give them notice of anything other than you were going to install comp time.
You didn't give them any notice that, quite contrary to what the statute indicates, that is, they may request it and the employer has to give it to them if it won't unduly disrupt.
It just doesn't seem... the statute doesn't seem to have space for a rule that says, and without prior notice you can require them to take it.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: It doesn't, but I don't think it's necessary, because I don't think that scheduling less than 40 hours a week is within the purview of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

Cashing them out at any time is, specifically, and so when we have the comp time agreement, which we have with the employees, it's to use the comp time, and then it's in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act, which it says, and so if we do that, though, within the Fair Labor Standards Act we can cash them out.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, Mr. Fleming, your opponent says he agrees with Judge Dennis' view that neither side was entitled to summary judgment, and that you go back to the district court for development of a factual record.
Do you disagree with that?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: No, I... yes, I disagree with that, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You think that your side was entitled to summary... that the county was entitled to summary judgment, as the Fifth Circuit said?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Absolutely.
On the deference issue, which was raised briefly by the opposing counsel, I would just say this.
The main case, of course, is Chevron, and the standard is if Congress has not directly spoke on the precise question... excuse me.
If the intent of Congress is clear, it's the end of the matter, and I think the intent is clear, if you look at what we're doing.
Shortening the work week is not within the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Cashing them out is.
Clearly, we can do it.

And as far as whether you use Chevron or you use Skidmore, Skidmore certainly is a lesser standard, but you can see in the regulations promulgated by the Secretary it cites Skidmore as to... that the regulation...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Wouldn't it be complicated... I understand you don't have that, but supposing your employees all had a contract that we'll work 40 hours a week.
Then what would you do?

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Then I think that they would be bound by contract law for that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So they couldn't... then you could not compel them to take the contract...

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: But their right would not arise from the Fair Labor Standards Act.
It would be under the contract.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would be based on the contract, okay.

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Well...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You don't have to use all your time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: michael_p_fleming
turn.label: Mr. Michael P. Fleming
turn.text: I was going to invite some more questions, but I will... if there aren't any more questions, Mr. Chief Justice, I'll just stop there.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Fleming.
The case is submitted.
The Honorable Court is now adjourned until Monday next at ten o'clock.
